intro: Braya involucrata, commonly known as the sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbage plants. The plant is characterized by its small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pink, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid environments. Braya involucrata is adapted to withstand drought conditions and has a low, spreading growth habit.
